name: N-[2,4-dibromo-6-(phenylcarbonyl)phenyl]acetamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3374

name: N-[2,4-dibromo-6-(phenylcarbonyl)phenyl]acetamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3374
Reason:
To predict the melting point of N-[2,4-dibromo-6-(phenylcarbonyl)phenyl]acetamide, we need to consider the impact of each functional group and the structural features on the melting point compared with a reference compound. Benzene, as a base unit, has a melting point of 5.5 °C. The functional groups and structural features that will affect the melting point are as follows: 

- Bromine substituents: Each Br likely adds to the melting point due to the increase in molecular weight and the polarizability. Since there are two bromines, this will have a substantial effect. (estimate: +40 °C per Br)
- Acetamide group (NC(=O)C): This group can form hydrogen bonds which should significantly raise the melting point. (estimate: +70 °C)
- Benzoyl group (C(=O)c1ccccc1): The ability of the carbonyl group to participate in additional intermolecular forces also raises the melting point. (estimate: +50 °C)

These estimates are on top of the base benzene unit. We sum the effects to predict the melting point.
Prediction:
Benzene base unit: 5.5 °C
+ Bromine substituents: +80°C (2 * +40 °C)
+ Acetamide group: +70°C
+ Benzoyl group: +50°C
Predicted melting point = 5.5 + 80 + 70 + 50 = 205.5 °C

name: N-[2,4-dibromo-6-(phenylcarbonyl)phenyl]acetamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3374
Reason:
To predict the melting point of N-[2,4-dibromo-6-(phenylcarbonyl)phenyl]acetamide, we examine the individual contributions of the functional groups present in the molecule, based on the basic benzene unit. Benzene has a melting point of 5.5 °C as a reference. The effects of the functional groups are estimated as follows: 

- Bromine substituents: Bromine atoms are heavy and highly polarizable, which can significantly increase the melting point due to increased molecular weight and stronger intermolecular interactions. With two bromine atoms, we can expect a substantial cumulative effect. (estimated effect: +30 °C per Br)
- Acetamide group (NC(=O)C): This group can increase the capacity for hydrogen bonding over benzene, which significantly enhances the melting point. (estimated effect: +40 °C)
- Benzoyl group (C(=O)c1ccccc1): The incorporation of another aromatic ring with a carbonyl group increases the potential for π-π interactions and dipole-dipole interactions, also raising the melting point. (estimated effect: +50 °C)

Adding these estimated effects to the benzene base unit gives us the predicted melting point.
Prediction: 5.5 °C (benzene base) + 60°C (2 * +30 °C for Br substituents) + 40°C (acetamide group) + 50°C (benzoyl group) = 155.5 °C
